definition[0]: to get or achieve something that will be permanent, especially after a lot of effort
example[0]: Boyd’s goal secured his team’s place in the Cup Final.
example[1]: Negotiators are still working to secure the hostages’ release.
example[2]: Redgrave won his third Olympic gold medal, and secured his place in history.
example[3]: The company secured a $20 million contract.
definition[1]: to make something safe from being attacked, harmed, or lost
example[4]: Troops were sent to secure the border.
example[5]: an agreement to secure the future of the rainforest
example[6]: They built a ten-foot high fence to secure the house against intruders.
definition[2]: to fasten or tie something firmly in a particular position
example[7]: John secured the boat firmly to the jetty.
definition[3]: if you secure a debt or a loan, you legally promise that, if you cannot pay back the money you have borrowed, you will give the lender goods or property of the same value instead
example[8]: He used his house to secure the loan.
definition[4]: a situation that is secure is one that you can depend on because it is not likely to change
example[9]: There are no secure jobs these days.
example[10]: We want a secure future for our children.
example[11]: United’s position at the top of the league seems relatively secure.
definition[5]: locked or guarded so that people cannot get in or out or steal anything
example[12]: The house isn’t very secure – we need some new locks.
example[13]: Keep your passport in a secure place.
example[14]: In the last year, only three children under the age of 14 have had to be placed in secure accommodation.
definition[6]: safe from and protected against damage or attack
example[15]: Companies can offer secure credit card transactions over the Internet.
example[16]: These elephants are relatively secure from poachers.
definition[7]: feeling confident about yourself and your abilities
example[17]: We want our children to be secure and feel good about themselves.
definition[8]: feeling confident and certain about a situation and not worried that it might change
example[18]: Workers no longer feel secure about the future.
example[19]: It was enough money to make us feel financially secure.
example[20]: We huddled together, secure in the knowledge that the rescue helicopter was on its way.
definition[9]: firmly fastened or tied, and not likely to fall down
example[21]: Are you sure that shelf is secure?
definition[10]: to get something you need after a lot of effort
example[22]: The airline has secured financing of $150 million from private sponsors.
definition[11]: to promise a lender that they can take certain assets, such as property or shares, if their loan is not paid back within the agreed time limit
example[23]: Borrowers generally are required to secure a loan with personal property as collateral.
example[24]: The debt is secured on some of the company’s assets.
definition[12]: investments or companies which are secure are not likely to lose money
example[26]: Higher yields are considered to be less secure.
definition[13]: feeling confident about a particular situation, especially one which concerns the future
example[27]: The frequent announcements of staff cuts are making Americans feel less secure in their jobs.
definition[14]: safe and protected from damage, change, being stolen etc
example[28]: Customers want guarantees that cash machines will be secure from unauthorized use.
example[29]: The single currency is giving industry more secure operating conditions.
